Equipment that falls into one of these categories is specified in accordance with these standards by the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist; with input from Operations, the Process Engineer, and the Maintenance Supervisor as appropriate. Equipment is purchased by the Warehouse Clerk in accordance with the specifications and at the direction of the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist. Equipment is installed in accordance with the standards at the direction of the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist. The Pressure Equipment Inspector, in accordance with plant inspection procedures, provides quality assurance for the purchase and installation of pressure equipment, tankage, heat exchangers, relief equipment and piping. Quality assurance for the installation of electrical equipment and instrumentation is provided by adherence to testing procedures developed by the Control Systems Specialist. 

Some of the non-pressure equipment in the plant is specially engineered for its service. Shell Engineering Standards are used for specifying, purchasing, and installing such equipment where applicable (for example, standards for electrical motors are applicable), but not all aspects of the equipment design and installation are covered by Shell standards. In these cases, the Plant Engineer and/or the Control Systems Specialist or an engineer working at their direction reviews equipment design.

Inspection of Pressure Equipment. Pressure equipment includes pressure vessels, exchangers, air coolers, piping, relief devices, tanks, and some non-pressurized equipment including cooling water towers, thermal oxidizers, flares, and process heaters. The Pressure Equipment Inspector is certified to API 510 (Pressure Equipment), API 570 (Piping), and API 653 (Tanks), and inspects equipment in accordance with these standards, as well as other equipment-specific recommended practices, Shell written best practices, and

MCP HSSE Procedures. The Pressure Equipment Inspector maintains a record of each inspection and schedules future ones. Inspection documentation is maintained for the life of the equipment. The Plant Engineer reviews unusual inspection results. The Plant Engineer and Technical Manager work with the Pressure Equipment Inspector to ensure that inspections are completed as required, documentation is completed, and inspection results are considered in setting inspection intervals. The frequency of inspections varies based on a risk-based algorithm developed and used by Shell. Equipment that is deteriorated beyond acceptable limits is repaired or retired.

Written Maintenance Procedures. Written general maintenance procedures are contained in the HSSE procedures manual and are reviewed on a periodic basis by technical staff. These procedures outline the maintenance organization, and work flow and address specific maintenance functions. Maintenance on non-pressure equipment is performed in accordance with the original equipment manufacturer's instructions or industry best practices. Maintenance on non-pressure equipment may be contracted by the Maintenance Supervisor to service companies that specialize in maintenance of specific equipment. Written maintenance procedures are reviewed and updated every three years. The maintenance procedures specify the date of the last update as well as when the next three-year update is due.

Inspection and Maintenance Practices to Maintain Integrity of Structural Components. MCP vessel inspection procedures include requirements for inspection of structural components and fireproofing at each external inspection. Significant maintenance work has been completed on replacement of deteriorated fireproofing in the plant.

Security Risk/Vulnerability Assessment (SRA)

The MCP Security Risk Assessment (SRA) was performed during February 2018 by a team of security professionals and the Senior Environmental Advisor. The SRA is performed at least every five years. The SRA includes data gathering and analysis to assess security risks and to determine the need for upgrading countermeasures in support of the Shell security risk management program. The assessment was performed using the Shell Standard Risk Assessment Methodology. The Shell SRA methodology is consistent with the most current guidance available via API 780 Standard for SRA. The assessment is based on the collection of background information, an on-site survey, and the subsequent analysis of that information. MCP HSSE also conducts a separate annual review of Site Security practices.

Members of the SMR Health and Safety Department, Auxiliary Fire Crew, and/or the Response Action Team (RAT) periodically conduct familiarization tours or tabletop reviews of the MCP facilities. A representative of the Contra Costa Fire District also inspects the MCP periodically. Regular red tag or field simulation drills are conducted in the field to test operational response. 
A periodic emergency drill is also conducted by SMR in conjunction with various outside agencies. As appropriate, SMR, MCP, and/or the applicable emergency response agencies work together to resolve any deficiencies identified during the drill. This pre-planning activity ensures that the members of the responding agencies are familiar with SMR/MCP facilities, the hazards of various extremely hazardous materials, the resources available at SMR/MCP, and their location. It also clearly identifies the capabilities and limitations of each responding agency. Copies of the drill records, including recommendations and critiques, are maintained at SMR and/or MCP.
 
MCP will also work closely with CCCHSD regarding any necessary response to hazardous material releases, to assist in determining requirements for downwind air monitoring, and to alert the public of the accidental release of EDA or aqueous ammonia. SMR/MCP worked with CCCHSD to establish Telephone Emergency Network System (TENS) zones that will be notified of the incident through the Community Warning System for any Level 2 or 3 incidents. 
 
The emergency response program, including the EAP and the ERP, is reviewed annually to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Employees are trained on the emergency response program when initially hired, when the emergency response plan is revised, and when employees' responsibilities are changed.

The EAP/ERP for SMR/MCP includes employee evacuation routes, head counting procedures, and training for employees. The agencies and individuals represent local emergency responders (e.g., Fire Department), public notification and regulatory reporting requirements (e.g., CCCHSD), and internal notification (e.g., Site Manager, Corporate Headquarters). The notification list requires that designated personnel make the notifications, and that they document when the telephone calls were placed, and the name and position of the person contacted. Completed Notification Matrices are maintained for five years.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Overall safety at MCP is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases. MCP has implemented an emergency response program to minimize the effects of accidental releases on employees, the public, and the environment. MCP's emergency response program is covered under contract with the broader emergency action plan/emergency response plan (EAP/ERP) administered by the Shell Martinez Refinery (SMR). The SMR EAP/ERP provides a complete range of emergency response services to MCP including a full incident command system, Auxiliary Fire Crew, a Hazardous Materials Team, a Confined Space Rescue Team, and an Emergency Medical Team (EMT). In addition:

Initial Agency Incident Response, Incident Command, and Incident Control would come from the California Highway Patrol (CHP) and/or the Contra Costa Fire District (or their designees). Field Contractor Employees who touch process equipment are required to receive basic training through an approved external industry-sponsored provider before being allowed on site. In addition, Field Contract Employees receive a site-specific HSSE orientation before they begin work. This orientation covers site hazards, process safety basics, and emergency issues including emergency notification, emergency access, muster points, shelter-in-place, and egress and evacuation routes. This orientation, which is repeated annually, includes a video, test, and issuance of the MCP Basic HSSE Requirements Handbook. Field contractors who have completed MCP-specific training are provided with an identification sticker for their hard hats.

The HSSE Department reviews selected Contractor and their performance as part of a quarterly ISN review. The MCP ensures that proper training is provided, and documentation maintained for each contractor. 
 
THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

MCP has compiled a five-year accident history for all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The compilation of this information satisfies the requirements of Section 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation. The five-year accident history allows MCP to explain to the community the factors causing or contributing to accidental releases, the onsite and offsite impacts of accidental releases, and the procedural and technological changes made to minimize the likelihood that this accidental release will occur again. The intent of this information exchange is to create an informed community while also documenting that accidental releases are investigated, and concrete changes are made to protect against reoccurrence.

Contractors

MCP relies on contractors to supplement the existing workforce during routine operations, maintenance, turnarounds, and construction projects. MCP and all Contract Owners are jointly responsible for safety and must ensure that Contractors are trained in and understand the following:

¿	Work practices necessary to perform the job;
¿	Hazards associated with a process;

¿	Applicable safe work practices. 

It is also critical that Contractors:

¿	Follow MCP's HSSE rules, including safe work practices, and
¿	Inform Shell of any unique hazards that they introduce while performing their work.

MCP has developed a Contractor Program, satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.12 of the CalARP regulation, to ensure that safety issues are addressed during contractor selection and that owner and Contractor Owner share responsibility for the safety of all employees (including Contractors). The Contractor Program is beneficial to release prevention because it thoroughly evaluates contractors to ensure that well-qualified, trained, and safe Contractors are used onsite.

MCP requires that potential Contract Owners answer specific questions regarding their HSSE programs. For Contractors that manipulate process equipment, this is normally done as part of the ISN service. ISN and MCP, in turn review this information against established criteria (e.g., accident records, worker's compensation factors, etc.). This information also includes data regarding any unique hazards that might be introduced during the course of their work. The MCP HSSE Committee discusses employee participation issues as part of their periodic meetings. Electronic copies of meeting minutes are posted onto the HSSE website and shared with workers in the field. Meeting minutes are retained for a minimum of 5 years. 

Hot Work Permits

Controlling ignition sources is vital to the MCP's accidental release prevention program. Therefore, it is critical that pertinent personnel are notified when hot work (any spark-producing operation including use of power tools, grinding, burning, welding, brazing) is to be performed and that appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work. MCP has developed a hot work permit program that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.11 of the CalARP regulation. This program requires that employees complete permits certifying that the applicable portions of the fire prevention and protection requirements are implemented prior to beginning hot work operations. These requirements are contained in the fire prevention and suppression procedure and hot work permit, Title 8 California Code of Regulations (T8 CCR) §4848 and §6777 respectively. 

The Operations department authorizes maintenance and other work in their area and issues permits for all hot work (e.g. grinding, burning, welding, and brazing) performed on or near covered processes. The hot work permit is terminated when conditions within the work environment become unsafe or hazardous, when conditions of its issuance change.

Employee Participation

MCP relies on the expertise of employees (including hourly and contract employees) at all levels and disciplines to optimize operations and safety and maintain an effective release prevention program. This is achieved by consulting with (i.e., exchanging information with, and soliciting input and participation from) personnel to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. MCP has developed a written employee participation plan (HSSE-002) that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and the requirements of Section 2760.1 of the CalARP regulation. The written employee participation plan (available in hard copy or through the local area network) ensures that:

¿	Employees and their representatives are consulted on the conduct and development of PHAs conducted to comply with OSHA PSM and Section 2760.2 of the CalARP regulation.

¿	Employees and their representatives are consulted on the development of all elements of the release prevention program, the hazard assessment performed in accordance with OSHA PSM and Sections 2750.1 through 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation, and the emergency response program developed in accordance with Section 2765.2 of the CalARP regulation. Examples of participation include:

1.	Operations and maintenance employees being actively involved in the development of procedures;

the process, and other employees (including contract employees as applicable) knowledgeable in the operation, design, and maintenance of the process. The team members are trained in the incident investigation process and requirements. The incident investigation team leader is responsible for initiating the investigation as soon as possible, but definitely within 48 hours of the time of the incident or PSM near miss. 

The incident investigation involves four stages. The HSSE Manager oversees the completion of these four stages, and the Line Manager has the operational responsibility for these stages. The other team members are responsible for participating and taking direction at the stages as requested relying on their training and experience: 

¿	Gathering evidence (involves interviewing witnesses, taking photographs, collecting evidence and records, and obtaining samples as applicable); 

¿	Analyzing the evidence (also involves identification of root cause if a root cause analysis was performed);
	
¿	Developing conclusions; and
	 
¿	Formulating recommendations

The incident investigation team prepares a written report at the conclusion of the investigation that includes (as applicable) a completed root cause information, required action items, or other applicable items. Recommendations are developed as part of a root cause analysis. Items are discussed individually and as part of Management meetings. Recommendations that result from the incident investigation are entered into the FIM System or Action Item Database, where an employee is assigned to the corrective action for the recommendation and is responsible for the closure of the recommendation by the assigned due date. Recommendations from the incident investigation will be communicated through a variety of meetings (HSSE Committee, Employee Team Meetings, Leadership Team, Plant Manager update) to the employees (including contractors), the county, the public, and the surrounding neighbors as appli

ger is also responsible for compiling periodic status reports for the recommendations and maintaining the associated records. Recommendations are tracked to completion. 
 
Incident Investigation

MCP believes that incident investigation is vital to the overall OSHA PSM/RMP/CalARP prevention program. MCP has developed an incident investigation procedure that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.9 of the CalARP regulation. Its purpose is to investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a release of EDA, or any other acutely hazardous materials that could have caused personnel injury or major property damage. Personnel identify underlying cause(s) and develop and implement corrective actions to prevent reoccurrence of the incident or similar incidents. A proximate cause analysis is performed for significant incidents (e.g., onsite fatality, significant offsite health effects). 

MCP management has stressed to employees the importance of reporting all PSM and other near-miss situations. A PSM near miss is an incident that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release. Employees are reminded that the proximate cause(s) of minor incidents and PSM near misses could result in major incidents if uncorrected. Employees are encouraged to report minor incidents and PSM near misses to Supervision or HSSE either verbally, in writing, or anonymously.

The Site Manager or Production Manager determines whether an incident investigation is warranted and charters a team to do the work. MCP uses root-cause methodology and analysis, and employees are appropriately trained.

A person trained in root cause techniques (e.g. Tripod, etc.) assumes the position of incident investigation team leader when an incident occurs. The number and experience of the team members is dependent upon the severity and complexity of the incident. Typically, the incident investigation teams are comprised of a team leader, an expert in

Internal compliance audits are performed at least every three years to review and evaluate the written documentation/records and implementation of these programs. These audits are expected to last approximately 1-2 days. Potential areas that can be improved within the prevention program elements are identified and recommendations are formulated and implemented to ensure an effective and improved overall prevention program. The developed compliance audits program satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2760.8 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) regulation and the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard. PSM/RMP Compliance audits were conducted and certified in 1995, 1998, 2000, 2003, 2005, 2008, 2011, 2014, and 2017.

A PSM/RMP Compliance Audit team for MCP will consist of one or more qualified HSSE personnel, any necessary technical staff resources, plus one or more designated Union representatives that are knowledgeable in the processes being audited. The Audit Leader is currently the HSSE Manager and a qualified third party. The Union representative(s) will be chosen by the Union (subject to confirmation by MCP). The Audit protocol will be based on OSHA Instruction CPL 2-2.45A CH-1 (PSM Program Elements) or similar Checklist, Shell Audit Guidelines, County input, and the results of previous PSM/RMP findings.

Audit Team members develop a list of recommendations for improvement. The results of the compliance audit are then communicated to interested personnel and contractors via established Plant communications channels (including the MCP HSSE Committee). The HSSE Manager then reviews the recommendations, determines the appropriate resolution of each recommendation, and assign responsibility for each recommendation. The HSSE Mana

MCP includes three OSHA PSM or EPA RMP processes. Modifications to these processes are sometimes required to improve safety and operability. When these modifications require a significant update to PSI, or if it is a new process, employees formally verify that all controls (engineering and administrative) are installed and implemented prior

Change Management

Process changes are sometimes necessary to address safety, environmental, and operational concerns. A change made in one part of a process may have unintended effects on other parts because the process is an integrated operation. Changes are therefore appropriately scrutinized before they are made to ensure that the changes do not compromise the safety and integrity of the process, and to avoid adverse effects to worker and public safety and the environment.

MCP has developed a written Change Management Procedure (MCP Procedure HSSE-100) that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.6 of the CalARP regulations. The Production Manager identifies required training and the employees who must receive the training to operate the covered process with new changes. Communication of the changes and required training of affected employees is completed prior to the start-up of the impacted process. During the Change Management process, a document update plan, which includes P

This was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at a minimum of every three years. Training documentation is provided through the Training Lead.  Detailed training may also be required because of a specific MOC or PSSR. Line Supervision is responsible for ensuring that the necessary training is conducted prior to implementation of the change to satisfy the MOC and PSSR program requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.6 and 2760.7 (respectively) of the CalARP regulation. 

Mechanical Integrity (MI)

A well-established mechanical integrity (MI) program ensures that equipment critical to process safety is fabricated to meet process specifications, installed correctly, and maintained in a safe operating condition. It also allows Maintenance Employees to proactively identify and correct equipment deficiencies to avoid associated incidents and down time. MCP has developed an MI program satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.5 of the CalARP regulation. The MI program applies to pressure vessels, heat exchangers, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, and any additional equipment deemed by Operations and Maintenance to be important to safety (e.g., fire protection equipment, specific pieces of rotating equipment, electrical equipment, and process controls).

Training

MCP believes that employees who clearly understand how to safely operate a process can significantly decrease the number and severity of incidents. Therefore, a thorough training program focused on specific operating procedures and safe work practices is a key element of an effective prevention program. 

MCP's HSSE Department has developed a written training program to provide employees (those involved with operating covered processes) with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process, and the hazards associated with the process. The training program also instructs personnel how to operate the process within safe operating limits, and how to handle potential emergencies. The training program satisfies the requirements of Section 2760.4 of the CalARP regulation and is comprised of initial training, periodic refresher training, hazard-specific training based on MOCs, PSSRs, and other activities, and documentation. The main specific tools used for this purpose are the MCP Training Catalog and Shell Open University software package.

Operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment. Specifically, new Operators receive initial training and Unit Qualification instruction. The Operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process. The training criteria is documented in job skill matrices that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system set points) and demonstration skills (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures). Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstration

and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and,
	
¿	A list of applicable safety systems (e.g., alarms, interlocks, emergency systems and shutdowns), their functions, and their set points.

Operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) were prepared by technical and hourly staff based on a careful review of each operating mode, recognition of the hazards involved, and the appropriate standard sequence of safe operating steps. These procedures are periodically reviewed and updated by staff and line personnel to reflect current practices.

The operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) are maintained current and accurate through regular review cycles, MOC reviews, and annual certification by Operations. The MOC procedure is also used to manage temporary operating procedures. The MOC review is dependent upon the complexity of the change and is performed as described in the MOC Procedure.

In the operating procedures portion of the covered process, there are no tables or safe operating limits, troubleshooting guide, or a list of applicable safety systems as they apply. However, the above information is available in central Ensure Safe Production (ESP) tables and elsewhere for the EO process and the other (RM-17) process in the facility. 

Process related actionable alarms for the facility are kept in ESP tables. Parameters monitored for alarm conditions include level indicators, temperature indicators, and pressure indicators. The specific alarm conditions in the ESP tables are:

¿	Alarm values for High-High (HH), High (H), Low (L), and Low-Low (LL) deviations
¿	Shutdown (S/D) values for High and Low Triggers and for a General Trigger condition 
¿	Notes documenting the alarm strategy and intention

A Description of the Martinez Catalyst Plant and the Regulated Substances Handled

MCP consists of 2 main batch processes: Ethylene Oxide (EO) Catalyst and RM-17. The EO Catalyst Process produces a silver-based catalyst sold to industrial customers that convert hydrocarbons to ethylene oxide. A specially formulated impregnating solution is produced at MCP and absorbed onto carrier pellets to make the EO Catalyst products. 

The RM-17 product is manufactured by reacting a proprietary raw material (containing toluene as a carrier) with a heavy olefin in the presence of a liquid catalyst. A series of simple distillation steps removes the lighter boiling components (including the toluene). The purified product is then shipped to other Shell Chemical facilities for further use in the process of manufacturing detergent products.

Please note that for the purposes of this RMP document, accidental release scenarios have only been determined for RMP regulated substances (e.g., ethylene diamine used on the EO Catalyst Process). However, the management system, prevention program, and emergency response elements discussed later in the document apply to the entire MCP Site.
